feed.title: Combined summary - [Opt-in full-RBF] Zero-conf apps in immediate danger

entry.title: Combined summary - [Opt-in full-RBF] Zero-conf apps in immediate danger
entry.summary: The bitcoin-dev community has been discussing the deployment of zero-conf applications and whether to switch mainnet mining and relay nodes over to full RBF. While there are risks associated with Bitcoin payments, solutions such as using Lightning for fast payments or accepting the zero-conf risk and covering oneself with an insurance premium have been suggested. However, the adoption of full RBF is already underway, making it too late to prevent its use.The only viable solution for fast payment processing is to use Lightning, a network built on top of Bitcoin that allows for instant settlement with minimal risk. GAP600, a company that guarantees zero confirmed Bitcoin and other crypto transactions, has expressed concern about the impact of full RBF becoming default-enabled and significantly adopted. To mitigate risk, GAP600 suggests continuing business as usual, managing risk, waiting for confirmations if the risk is too high, and using Lightning if possible. Coinspaid, a Berlin-based cryptocurrency processing company, relies heavily on Bitcoin zero conf and expresses satisfaction with the zero-conf flows provided by GAP600.There are concerns about the immediate risk to existing businesses still accepting unconfirmed transactions. Some developers dismiss the risks, while others argue that they should be made clear to enable businesses to take action and avoid potential harm. The decision to remove the option to disable RBF policy has been met with criticism, as it does not take into account feedback from users and businesses who are affected by the change.Overall, the discussion revolves around the deprecation of accepting unconfirmed on-chain payments, the deployment of zeroconf applications, and whether to switch mainnet mining and relay nodes over to full RBF. There are concerns about the immediate risk to existing businesses still accepting unconfirmed transactions and the potential impact of delaying the implementation of zeroconf.Bitcoin's current transaction confirmation process involves waiting for a certain number of blocks to be added to the blockchain. This can lead to delays in payments and frustration for users. However, the introduction of Replace-by-Fee (RBF) has allowed users to speed up their transactions by replacing an unconfirmed transaction with a new one that includes a higher fee. While this has benefits for users, it also presents risks as it could potentially enable double spending attacks.The bitcoin-dev mailing list has been discussing the adoption of opt-in Replace-by-Fee (RBF) policies, which allow users to replace unconfirmed transactions with higher fee versions. Muun Wallet found that this poses a problem for zero-conf applications and suggested delaying deployment. Bitrefill expressed concern about the ease of systematic abuse by users, while Sergej Kotliar warned of the dangers of RBF as a default policy and suggested rejecting all RBF payments. There is debate over whether to continue supporting unconfirmed on-chain payments indefinitely or drawing a line in the sand now.Dave proposed incremental steps towards full RBF without sudden leaps, while Antoine Riard invited John Carvalho to further develop his argument against full RBF. Concerns were raised about developers making assumptions about businesses rather than speaking to them, and there were discussions around systematic exploitation by bad actors and whether this could lead to something else needing to be done with RBF payments.While Lightning accounts for 15% of total Bitcoin payments, concerns were raised about disabling on-chain commerce to encourage its adoption. The efficacy of RBF and CPFP as solutions to unstuck stuck transactions was also discussed, along with finding alternative solutions to retail wallets. The discussion emphasized the need for continued development and improvement of Bitcoin's infrastructure to provide better options for transacting on the network.The Bitcoin-dev community debated the responsibility of Core contributors and maintainers to provide options and recommendations regarding mempool policies, with calls for clearer communication regarding risk and a timeline for deployment. The developers of three main coinjoin implementations affected by opt-in RBF have not made any remarks. The conversation also touched on ensuring the sustainability and decentralization of Bitcoin practices, with proposals to enable experimentation with zeroconf deprecation on test nets before implementing it on mainnet. The decision to break backwards compatibility with legacy wallets and services that use zeroconf and other outdated features was also discussed.The CEO of GAP600 expressed concern over the potential adoption of full RBF, while John Carvalho argued that merchants accepting base layer Bitcoin is crucial for adoption rather than just Lightning Network. Overall, the discussion emphasized the importance of considering feedback and avoiding harm to users, even if it means delaying a release or engaging in "bikeshedding" to ensure that the right decision is made.
